title: Big 12 Power rankings: Baylor now No. 1 and rest of league shuffled after chaotic Saturday
text:
CLOSE USA TODAY Sports' Paul Myerberg breaks down the latest Amway Coaches Poll. USA TODAY

Now that everyone’s back to reality and calmed down after Chaotic Saturday in the Big 12, what’s it all mean after four favorites lost?

It means that Baylor, which escaped the madness while not even playing Saturday, is the league’s lone unbeaten.

It means that Oklahoma, which lost against a Kansas State team that gets more surprising as the season progresses, still isn’t out of the hunt for a spot in the College Football Playoffs.

Let’s say the Sooners don’t lose again. Let’s say Lincoln Riley’s team beats Iowa State, Baylor, TCU and Oklahoma State to finish 8-1 in the league. Again, let’s assume they beat whomever they play in the Big 12 title game.

Baylor safety Henry Black (8) breaks up a pass intended for Oklahoma State tight end Logan Carter during the second half at Boone Pickens Stadium. (Photo: Rob Ferguson, USA TODAY Sports)

Does a 12-1 Oklahoma get invited to college football’s final four?

It’d be an interesting discussion among the College Football Playoff committee, that’s for sure.

Here we go with another round of the USA TODAY Network’s Big 12 power rankings.

No. 1 Baylor (7-0, 4-0 Big 12)

Last week’s ranking: 2

Last game: Idle.

In a nutshell: An unbeaten Baylor — that’d be 13-0 — makes the College Football Playoff. That’s reality. What we don’t know is the likelihood of Matt Rhule’s team finishing the regular season unscathed. Thursday night, the Bears host West Virginia. After that, they’re at TCU, and then there’s consecutive home games against Oklahoma and Texas, before finishing the regular season at Kansas.

On deck: Thursday vs. West Virginia, 8 p.m. ET, ESPN.

POWER RANKINGS: ACC | Big 12 | Big Ten | Pac-12 | SEC

RE-RANK: Oklahoma falls to No. 9 and the American Athletic shows strength

TIGERS MOVE UP: LSU now No. 2 behind Alabama in Amway Coaches poll

No. 2 Oklahoma (7-1, 4-1 Big 12)

Last week’s rating: 1

Last game: Lost to Kansas State 48-41.

In a nutshell: Here’s the deal: If the Sooners win the rest of their games, do they get into the College Football Playoff ahead of a second team from the Big Ten or SEC? That’ll shake out on Dec. 8, but this much is certain – Oklahoma’s first true road game loss since 2014 was a doozie. After a week off, Iowa State invades Norman, Oklahoma, and for both teams, the stakes will be monumental.

On deck: Nov. 9 vs. Iowa State.

No. 3 Kansas State (5-2, 2-2 Big 12)

Last week’s rating: 5

Last game: Defeated Oklahoma 48-41.

In a nutshell: Check out the rest of the schedule — at Kansas, at Texas, home against West Virginia, at Texas Tech and at home against Iowa State. See anything there that’s more daunting than what Chris Klieman’s team did last Saturday? The mission now is to keep all Wildcats emotionally grounded.

On deck: Saturday at Kansas, 3:30 p.m. ET, FS1.

No. 4 Texas (5-3, 3-2 Big 12)

Last week’s rating: 3

Last game: Lost to TCU 37-27.

In a nutshell: Saturday was going to be tough, anyway, for quarterback Sam Ehlinger, but four interceptions? He came into the game with just three this season. It’s still possible for the Longhorns to make the Big 12 title game, although they face Iowa State and Baylor back-to-back on the road. There’s also a Nov. 9 home game against giant-killer Kansas State.

On deck: Nov. 9 vs. Kansas State.

No. 5 Oklahoma State (5-3, 2-3 Big 12)

Last week’s rating: 6

Last game: Defeated Iowa State 34-27.

In a nutshell: There wasn’t anything too fancy about intercepting three Brock Purdy passes during the game’s final 7 minutes. Cluster defenders in the middle of the field. Force the sophomore to pass into double- and sometimes triple coverage. He’d done it all day, and there was no reason to believe he’d stop. The fancy stuff was a screen pass that Tylan Wallace turned into a 71-yard touchdown, a 50-yard scoring screen pass to Braydon Johnson, and Chuba Hubbard’s 65-yard scoring bust through the heart of the defense.

On deck: Saturday vs. TCU at 3:30 p.m. ET, ESPN.

No. 6 Iowa State (5-3, 3-2 Big 12)

Last week’s rating: 4

Last game: Lost to Oklahoma State 34-27.

In a nutshell: Iowa State looked like Iowa State of old at times during this loss – shabby tackling on long runs, and a plethora of interceptions. There’s no sugar-coating the fallout of what happened at Jack Trice Stadium: Matt Campbell’s team must win its remaining four regular-season games if it hopes to play in the Big 12 championship game.

On deck: Nov. 9 at Oklahoma.

No. 7 TCU (4-3, 2-2 Big 12)

Last week’s rating: 7

Last game: Defeated Texas 37-27.

In a nutshell: Did Saturday’s outcome really surprise anyone? TCU coach Gary Patterson has beaten Texas six times during the past eight times they’ve played. “It helps me if I beat Texas; I can usually keep my job longer in this state,” Patterson told reporters after the game. “It helps me.”

On deck: Saturday at Oklahoma State, 3:30 p.m. ET, ESPN.

No. 8 Kansas (3-5, 1-4 Big 12)

Last week’s rating: 10

Last game: Defeated Texas Tech 37-34.

In a nutshell: Coach Les Miles waited too long to replace offensive coordinator Les Koenning with Brent Dearmon. First, it was a 48-point explosion during his first game in a two-point loss against Texas, and last Saturday, it was drawing up a successful offense against Texas Tech.

On deck: Saturday vs. Kansas State, 3:30 p.m. ET, FS1.

No. 9 West Virginia (3-4, 1-3 Big 12)

Last week’s rating: 8

Last game: Idle.

In a nutshell: A three-game losing streak just got worse. Suddenly what looked like possibly a comfy final four games isn’t so comfy. The Mountaineers’ November schedule includes games at Kansas State, at home against Oklahoma State, at TCU – after playing Thursday at Baylor.

On deck: Thursday at Baylor at 8 p.m. ET, ESPN.

No. 10 Texas Tech (3-5, 1-4 Big 12)

Last week’s rating: 9

Last game: Lost to Kansas 37-34.

In a nutshell: Where’s this program headed, after losing against Kansas? Five losses out of the past six games, including four out of five against the Big 12, has to have Red Raider fans wondering.

On deck: Nov. 9 at West Virginia.
description: A Saturday that saw Oklahoma and other favorites loss has shaken up the Big 12 power rankings. Baylor now leads the Sooners with Kansas State third.
